body: I have the same issue, with the same version for Vagrant and vbox, and a Vagrant file generated with puphpet. What is worst is that some changes on disk are not persisted (like changing .bashrc), possibly due to the reprovision.

issue.title: `vagrant resume` takes a long time

repository.name: trellis
repository.description: WordPress LEMP stack with PHP 8.3, Composer, WP-CLI and more

issue.body: `vagrant resume` after `vagrant suspend` takes so long time ... is it normal?

body: I'm seeing this as well with v1.8.1

Same problem with Vagrant 1.8.1:
vagrant resume -> runs provision
Doesn't fix the core issue, but after `vagrant suspend` I always run `vagrant up` to bring the VM back up, and provisioner is not run.
This has happened to me on two different VMs now when resuming with 1.8.1.

Here it is also going the same problem.

```
- Windows 10
- Virtualbox 5.0.14
- Vagrant 1.8.1
(Always running vagrant as administrator)
```

the same problem .
1. vagrant suspend then vagrant resume ==> run provision
2. vagrant snapshot save init then vagrant snapshot restore init ==> run provision

I have to vagrant halt first and then go to vritualbox , restore the snapshot , then vagrant up.

Confirm the problem vagrant resume runs provision.
Windows 10 host
Vagrant 1.8.1
Virtualbox 5.0.14

Same problem here, this is the workaround to resume and skip provision:

`vagrant up --no-provision`

issue.title: Do not ignore the sentinal file when running resume

repository.name: vagrant
repository.description: Vagrant is a tool for building and distributing development environments.

issue.body:
### Overview

Do not ignore the sentinal file when running resume and prevent running provisioners again.
### References
- Fixes #6787 

The sentinal file was always being ignored when running the resume command. This is fixed along with allowing provision options to be used with resume. The code added aligns with the implementation in the reload command.

BTW, I did a `git bisect` to track it back to issue #5815 and commit 6f3ed13f75a1be66ed22f9bdcaa262e8077e458e. In the case of a resume command there was no options array passed into the `machine.action` call which caused the `env.key?(:provision_ignore_sentinel)` check in lib/vagrant/action/builtin/provision.rb to fail and `ignore_sentinal` defaulted to true.

issue.title: Vagrant resume always run provisioners

repository.name: vagrant
repository.description: Vagrant is a tool for building and distributing development environments.

issue.body:
I usually suspend my vagrant box; since I've updated it to version 1.8.x (I've tested with 1.8.0 and 1.8.1), each time that I resume the machine (`vagrant resume`), vagrant reload all the provisioners, when I was using 1.7.x I never had that issue and I tried to downgrade vagrant and still working as expected, so it looks that the changes in my machine shouldn't produce that different behaviour between 1.7.x and 1.8.x

I observed that if I resume the machine using `vagrant up`, then the provisioners aren't run; after I discovered that I can use `vagrant up` the issues is not very important, however now that I have more information about this expected behaviour, I thought that it may help to figure out what it's happening or may help to find other related issues.

Vagrant Version: Vagrant 1.8.1
Host OS: OSX El Capitan 10.11.13
Virtual Machine: Ubuntu server x64 Wily cloud image over VirtualBox (v5.0.16 r105871)
Vagrantfile: https://gist.github.com/ifraixedes/201a6f4e6dfdb85b6fcf

What should have happened? Not to run the provisioning each time I execute `vagrant resume`
What actually happened? It execute over and over the provisioning each time that I execute `vagrant resume`

repository.name: mh-opsworks
repository.description: An amazon OpsWorks implementation of a matterhorn cluster

body: Any progress on this since we generated the inifite loop with #7133 ?
Same here. A coworker was wonderung why I complained about resume running a provisioner. It turned out he was running a 1.7.x. We agreed that he shouldn't upgrade until this issue is fixed.
is there an ETA on when this will be solved?

> is there an ETA on when this will be solved?

Apparently the Vagrant was abandoned by @hashicorp :cry:
Vagrant has not been abandoned. We are a very small team and have not had the opportunity to test these new changes yet. Sorry!
Thanks guys for all your hard work. Vagrant is a hugely useful tool. @sethvargo
